desc_merge: In an outbreak scenario, a contact tracing graph [(0, 1), (0, 2), (0, 5), (1, 2), (1, 8), (1, 3), (2, 7), (3, 4), (3, 5), (3, 8), (3, 7), (4, 5), (4, 6), (4, 8), (5, 6), (5, 8), (5, 7), (6, 7), (6, 8), (7, 8)] with 9 individuals and 20 interactions is analyzed. To identify all potential infections, health officials must test the smallest possible group of people such that every close contact pair includes at least one tested individual, optimizing testing resources.

A building’s room adjacency graph [(0, 1), (0, 2), (1, 2), (3, 4), (3, 5), (4, 5), (6, 7), (6, 8), (7, 8)] has 9 rooms and 9 connecting doors. To deploy motion sensors efficiently, the goal is to cover all doorways by placing sensors in the fewest rooms, ensuring every door is monitored while minimizing installation costs.

A brand partnership graph [(0, 1), (0, 2), (1, 2), (3, 4), (3, 5), (3, 9), (3, 11), (3, 10), (4, 5), (4, 9), (5, 10), (5, 11), (6, 7), (6, 8), (6, 9), (7, 8), (7, 11), (7, 10), (8, 10), (8, 9), (8, 11), (9, 10), (9, 11), (10, 11)] models 12 influencers and 24 collaborations (e.g., co-promotions). To maximize reach with minimal budget, marketers select the smallest set of influencers such that every collaboration involves at least one chosen influencer, ensuring full campaign coverage.

A habitat connectivity graph [(0, 1), (0, 2), (0, 8), (1, 2), (1, 8), (1, 6), (2, 7), (3, 4), (3, 5), (3, 8), (3, 7), (3, 6), (4, 5), (4, 6), (4, 8), (4, 7), (5, 8), (5, 6), (6, 7), (6, 8), (7, 8)] represents 9 wildlife zones and 21 migration paths. Conservationists aim to protect the fewest zones while ensuring every migration route is adjacent to at least one protected area, balancing ecological preservation and land use.

A financial transaction graph [(0, 1), (0, 2), (0, 7), (0, 3), (0, 5), (1, 2), (1, 5), (1, 7), (2, 7), (2, 6), (2, 3), (3, 4), (3, 5), (3, 8), (3, 7), (3, 6), (4, 5), (4, 6), (4, 8), (4, 7), (5, 8), (5, 6), (6, 7), (6, 8), (7, 8)] links 9 accounts via 25 transfers. Auditors must flag the minimal set of accounts to investigate, ensuring every transaction involves at least one flagged account, thereby uncovering potential fraud rings with limited resources.

In a distribution network modeled as [(0, 1), (0, 2), (1, 2), (3, 4), (3, 5), (4, 5), (6, 7), (6, 8), (7, 8)] with 9 warehouses and 9 shipping routes, regulators must ensure all drug shipments are tracked. By selecting the smallest set of warehouses to audit, every route is monitored, minimizing regulatory overhead while preventing counterfeit goods.

An airline route map [(0, 1), (0, 2), (0, 9), (0, 10), (0, 11), (1, 2), (1, 11), (1, 10), (1, 9), (2, 10), (2, 9), (2, 11), (3, 4), (3, 5), (4, 5), (6, 7), (6, 8), (7, 8), (9, 10), (9, 11), (10, 11)] with 12 airports and 21 flight paths requires radar coverage. Strategically placing radar stations at the fewest airports ensures every flight path is observed, reducing infrastructure costs without compromising safety.

In a DNA fragment overlap graph [(0, 1), (0, 2), (1, 2), (3, 4), (3, 5), (4, 5), (6, 7), (6, 8), (7, 8)] with 9 fragments and 9 overlaps, scientists must verify critical fragments to detect sequencing errors. A minimal vertex cover identifies the fewest fragments needing validation to ensure all overlaps are error-free.

A cloud infrastructure graph [(0, 1), (0, 2), (0, 5), (1, 2), (1, 5), (1, 4), (2, 3), (2, 5), (3, 4), (3, 5), (3, 8), (4, 5), (4, 7), (5, 8), (5, 7), (5, 6), (6, 7), (6, 8), (7, 8)] with 9 servers and 19 communication links requires backup nodes. Selecting the smallest set of servers to replicate guarantees that every link remains operational if any single server fails, optimizing redundancy costs.

A historical site’s artifact proximity graph [(0, 1), (0, 2), (0, 5), (1, 2), (1, 5), (1, 3), (1, 4), (2, 3), (2, 4), (3, 4), (3, 5), (4, 5), (6, 7), (6, 8), (7, 8)] with 9 artifacts and 15 proximity relationships needs guarding. Placing sensors on the minimal number of artifacts ensures all proximity pairs are monitored against theft, balancing security and budget constraints.

In a community contact network [(0, 1), (0, 2), (0, 8), (1, 2), (1, 6), (2, 6), (2, 7), (2, 8), (3, 4), (3, 5), (3, 7), (3, 8), (3, 6), (4, 5), (4, 6), (4, 7), (4, 8), (5, 6), (5, 7), (5, 8), (6, 7), (6, 8), (6, 11), (6, 9), (7, 8), (7, 10), (8, 9), (8, 11), (9, 10), (9, 11), (10, 11)] with 12 individuals and 31 interactions, health officials aim to vaccinate the smallest group of people to block disease transmission. By selecting a minimal vertex cover, every interaction involves at least one vaccinated individual, ensuring efficient herd immunity.

A transportation network [(0, 1), (0, 2), (0, 7), (0, 11), (0, 6), (0, 8), (1, 2), (1, 11), (1, 8), (1, 7), (1, 6), (2, 8), (2, 9), (2, 6), (2, 10), (3, 4), (3, 5), (3, 10), (3, 11), (4, 5), (5, 11), (5, 10), (6, 7), (6, 8), (7, 8), (9, 10), (9, 11), (10, 11)] models 12 neighborhoods and 28 frequently traveled routes. To minimize costs, a ride-sharing company must place hubs in the fewest neighborhoods such that every route connects to at least one hub, ensuring coverage for all potential pickups.

A graph [(0, 1), (0, 2), (1, 2), (3, 4), (3, 5), (4, 5), (6, 7), (6, 8), (7, 8)] represents 9 voting districts and 9 shared boundaries where electoral fraud could occur. Authorities need to deploy observers to the smallest set of districts to monitor all adjacent boundaries, guaranteeing fair elections with minimal resources.

A website network [(0, 1), (0, 2), (0, 4), (0, 3), (0, 8), (0, 5), (0, 6), (1, 2), (1, 7), (1, 8), (1, 6), (1, 5), (2, 4), (2, 7), (2, 5), (3, 4), (3, 5), (4, 5), (6, 7), (6, 8), (7, 8)] has 9 pages and 21 hyperlinks. Advertisers want to place banners on the fewest pages possible while ensuring every hyperlink originates from or points to at least one page with an ad, maximizing visibility cost-effectively.

In a food web [(0, 1), (0, 2), (1, 2), (3, 4), (3, 5), (4, 5), (6, 7), (6, 8), (7, 8)] with 9 species and 9 predator-prey relationships, conservationists must protect the smallest set of species to disrupt all predation links. This ensures ecosystem stability by preventing unchecked population growth or collapse.

In a corporate intranet represented as [(0, 1), (0, 2), (1, 2), (3, 4), (3, 5), (3, 8), (3, 7), (3, 10), (3, 9), (3, 6), (3, 11), (4, 5), (4, 10), (4, 9), (4, 11), (5, 11), (5, 7), (5, 10), (5, 6), (5, 9), (6, 7), (6, 8), (7, 8), (9, 10), (9, 11), (10, 11)] with 12 devices and 26 connections, security analysts must deploy intrusion detection systems (IDS) to monitor all network traffic. By selecting a minimal set of devices to host IDS, every communication path is covered, ensuring threats are detected while minimizing deployment costs.

A railway network is modeled as [(0, 1), (0, 2), (0, 11), (0, 6), (1, 2), (1, 3), (1, 5), (1, 4), (1, 9), (2, 4), (2, 7), (2, 8), (2, 3), (2, 9), (3, 4), (3, 5), (3, 9), (4, 5), (4, 11), (5, 11), (6, 7), (6, 8), (6, 9), (6, 11), (7, 8), (7, 9), (8, 10), (8, 9), (8, 11), (9, 10), (9, 11), (10, 11)], where stations are nodes and tracks are edges. To ensure safety, inspectors must be stationed at key junctions to oversee all track segments. A retail supply chain is represented as [(0, 1), (0, 2), (0, 7), (0, 3), (0, 6), (0, 5), (0, 8), (1, 2), (1, 3), (1, 8), (1, 6), (1, 4), (2, 7), (2, 6), (2, 8), (3, 4), (3, 5), (3, 8), (3, 6), (4, 5), (4, 8), (5, 8), (6, 7), (6, 8), (7, 8)], where warehouses are nodes and delivery routes are edges. The MVC solution identifies the minimal set of warehouses to audit, ensuring full route coverage with 9 warehouses and 25 routes.

A city’s road intersection network is modeled as [(0, 1), (0, 2), (0, 7), (0, 4), (0, 3), (0, 8), (1, 2), (1, 7), (1, 8), (1, 4), (1, 6), (1, 3), (2, 7), (2, 3), (2, 5), (2, 8), (3, 4), (3, 5), (3, 6), (4, 5), (4, 7), (5, 6), (6, 7), (6, 8), (7, 8)] with 9 intersections and 25 roads. To optimize traffic flow, sensors must be installed at intersections to monitor all roads. The MVC problem finds the smallest set of intersections to equip, ensuring every road is observed without redundant sensors.

In a co-authorship network [(0, 1), (0, 2), (0, 9), (0, 11), (1, 2), (1, 11), (1, 10), (1, 9), (2, 10), (2, 11), (3, 4), (3, 5), (3, 6), (3, 9), (4, 5), (4, 9), (4, 10), (4, 8), (4, 11), (5, 7), (5, 6), (5, 9), (5, 8), (6, 7), (6, 8), (7, 8), (9, 10), (9, 11), (10, 11)] with 12 researchers and 29 collaborations, funding agencies must monitor research integrity. In an advanced power distribution network modeled as [(0, 1), (0, 2), (0, 7), (0, 5), (1, 2), (1, 5), (1, 4), (2, 8), (2, 4), (2, 6), (2, 3), (2, 5), (3, 4), (3, 5), (3, 7), (3, 8), (4, 5), (4, 7), (4, 8), (5, 7), (5, 8), (6, 7), (6, 8), (7, 8)] with 9 substations and 24 transmission lines, sensors must be deployed to detect faults. A city’s road network is represented as [(0, 1), (0, 2), (1, 2), (3, 4), (3, 5), (4, 5), (6, 7), (6, 8), (6, 9), (6, 10), (6, 11), (7, 8), (7, 10), (7, 11), (8, 9), (8, 10), (9, 10), (9, 11), (10, 11)], where nodes are intersections and edges are roads.
